The measurement of the national debt: The expert mentions that there are two ways to measure the national debt - the amount held by the public debt and the gross federal debt. The claim specifically refers to the debt held by the public, which is the debt borrowed by the federal government and held by investors through Treasury notes and other securities.
The starting point of measurement: The expert states that the Georgia Republican Party measured the federal debt held by the public starting from the time Obama was sworn in as president on January 20, 2009. This establishes the specific timeframe for which the claim is being made.
Increase in the national debt: The expert provides data on the national debt held by the public, showing that it was $6.3 trillion on January 20, 2009, and increased to nearly $10.5 trillion three years later. This information supports the claim that the debt has been increasing during Obama's presidency.
Projection for future debt: The expert mentions that the White House's Office of Management and Budget estimates that the debt held by the public will be about $12.8 trillion by the end of fiscal year 2013. This projection provides insight into the potential trajectory of the national debt during Obama's first term.
